Bacterial_spot.description: Bacterial spot is a bacterial infection that causes small, water-soaked lesions on leaves and fruits.
Bacterial_spot.cause: The disease is caused by the bacterium Xanthomonas spp.
Bacterial_spot.prevention: Use resistant varieties, avoid overhead irrigation, and practice crop rotation.

Early_blight.description: Early blight is caused by the fungus Alternaria solani, leading to dark, concentric ring lesions on leaves.
Early_blight.prevention: Plant resistant varieties, maintain good air circulation, and avoid overhead watering.
Early_blight.cure: Apply fungicides such as chlorothalonil or mancozeb.

Healthy.description: The plant is healthy with no visible symptoms of any diseases.
Healthy.prevention: Maintain good agricultural practices for overall plant health.

Late_blight.description: Late blight is a fungal disease caused by Phytophthora infestans, affecting leaves and fruits with brown lesions.
Late_blight.prevention: Use resistant varieties and avoid wet conditions for long periods.
Late_blight.cure: Apply fungicides like mefenoxam and metalaxyl.

Leaf_Mold.description: Leaf mold is caused by the fungus Passalora fulva, which leads to the development of yellow spots on leaves, especially in the lower part of the plant.
Leaf_Mold.prevention: Remove infected leaves, maintain good air circulation, and avoid wetting foliage.
Leaf_Mold.cure: Use fungicides like azoxystrobin or chlorothalonil.

Septoria_leaf_spot.description: Septoria leaf spot is caused by the fungus Septoria lycopersici, characterized by small, dark lesions with yellow halos on tomato leaves.
Septoria_leaf_spot.prevention: Avoid overhead irrigation, remove infected leaves, and use disease-free seeds.
Septoria_leaf_spot.cure: Apply fungicides such as chlorothalonil or copper-based solutions.

Two_spotted_spider_mite.description: The two-spotted spider mite causes yellowing of leaves and webbing on the plant.
Two_spotted_spider_mite.prevention: Use natural predators like ladybugs or apply insecticidal soap.
Two_spotted_spider_mite.cure: Insecticidal miticides or a strong spray of water can reduce the mite population.

Target_spot.description: Target spot is caused by the fungus Corynespora cassiicola, leading to circular lesions on the leaves.
Target_spot.prevention: Use resistant varieties, improve plant spacing, and avoid waterlogging.
Target_spot.cure: Fungicides like mancozeb or chlorothalonil can help control the disease.

Tomato_mosaic_virus.description: Tomato mosaic virus (ToMV) causes mottling and distortion of tomato leaves and fruits.
Tomato_mosaic_virus.cause: Viral infection caused by the Tomato mosaic virus.
Tomato_mosaic_virus.prevention: Use virus-free seeds and resistant varieties, and eliminate infected plants.
Tomato_mosaic_virus.cure: No cure; control involves managing symptoms and removing infected plants.

Tomato_yellow_leaf_curl_virus.description: Tomato yellow leaf curl virus (TYLCV) causes yellowing of leaves, stunting, and reduced fruit production.
Tomato_yellow_leaf_curl_virus.prevention: Control whitefly populations and use resistant tomato varieties.
Tomato_yellow_leaf_curl_virus.cure: No cure; use resistant varieties and manage whitefly infestations.
